Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A merger contract contains clauses that could expose the client to immediate financial liability if not examined promptly.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dive into the thick stack of merger documents on my desk. It was Sam, my oldest friend. His voice trembled, “Do you have a minute? I really need to talk.” I could hear the strain—he and his partner had been fighting again. As his friend, I knew he needed me to listen, to be present, to help him sort through the mess of his feelings. But as a lawyer, I was staring at a contract with clauses that could cost my client millions if I didn’t catch a loophole before the deadline tonight. My heart twisted. Sam expected comfort and undivided attention; my client expected sharp focus and immediate action. I stared at the phone, guilt and anxiety warring inside me, torn between being the friend Sam needed and the lawyer my client relied on.
